This last week, there was a major meeting in Ireland of the Anglican church clergy in which the problem of North American churches allowing practicing homosexuals as priests was addressed.
 
 It seems that the Anglican church is finally taking a stand here, and rightly deciding that biblical scripture, rather than political correctness, should guide the church as it always has.
 
 Here are the pertinent exerpts from the Communiqué regarding the meeting:
 6. We then proceeded to our own reflections on these responses. There are a number of things which are quite clear. Many primates have been deeply alarmed that the standard of Christian teaching on matters of human sexuality expressed in the 1998 Lambeth Resolution 1.10, which should command respect as the position overwhelmingly adopted by the bishops of the Anglican Communion, has been seriously undermined by the recent developments in North America. At the same time, it is acknowledged that these developments within the Episcopal Church (USA) and the Anglican Church of Canada have proceeded entirely in accordance with their constitutional processes and requirements (vi). We also wish to make it quite clear that in our discussion and assessment of the moral appropriateness of specific human behaviours, we continue unreservedly to be committed to the pastoral support and care of homosexual people. The victimisation or diminishment of human beings whose affections happen to be ordered towards people of the same sex is anathema to us. We assure homosexual people that they are children of God, loved and valued by him, and deserving of the best we can give of pastoral care and friendship (vii). 
 
 12. We as a body continue to address the situations which have arisen in North America with the utmost seriousness. Whilst there remains a very real question about whether the North American churches are willing to accept the same teaching on matters of sexual morality as is generally accepted elsewhere in the Communion, the underlying reality of our communion in God the Holy Trinity is obscured, and the effectiveness of our common mission severely hindered.
 
 13. We are persuaded however that in order for the recommendations of the Windsor Report to be properly addressed, time needs to be given to the Episcopal Church (USA) and to the Anglican Church of Canada for consideration of these recommendations according to their constitutional processes.
 
 14. Within the ambit of the issues discussed in the Windsor Report and in order to recognise the integrity of all parties, we request that the Episcopal Church (USA) and the Anglican Church of Canada voluntarily withdraw their members from the Anglican Consultative Council for the period leading up to the next Lambeth Conference. During that same period we request that both churches respond through their relevant constitutional bodies to the questions specifically addressed to them in the Windsor Report as they consider their place within the Anglican Communion. (cf. paragraph 8)
 
 18. In the meantime, we ask our fellow primates to use their best influence to persuade their brothers and sisters to exercise a moratorium on public Rites of Blessing for Same-sex unions and on the consecration of any bishop living in a sexual relationship outside Christian marriage. 
 
 19. These strategies are intended to restore the full trust of our bonds of affection across the Communion.

Gay activism is pretty much free to do as they want, but trying to destroy the church is not aceptable. There is no excuse to have driven this rift into the church the way it has.
 
 The entire communiqué can be read here: http://www.anglicancommunion.org/acns/articles/39/00/acns3948.cfm

 The context of the discussion was the moral stigma regarding homosexual actions, as well as the fact that churches don't always allow gay leaders--not the rights issue. Regarding rights guaranteed by the Constitution, you are correct in that religious views in and of themselves shouldn't determine constitutional interpretation, unless those views are the same as what would otherwise be good for or to protect society. That's easy to say on paper, but in the real world the moral views of the people of our country DO effect legislation and the election of officials. That's the just the way it is. 
 
 However, most arguments I hear regarding gay rights are not based solely on religion, which is what you seem to think. There are many who believe that gay relationships are harmful from a cause-and-effect standpoint (HIV infection rates among gay men have certainly had a hand in this). Others believe it is just too far out of the norm of social acceptability to be healthy. And regarding marriage, many people just want to simply protect the institution of marriage as it is, without changing it by making it more open-ended. Regardless of religion, they simply view the institution as too sacred to tamper with. (You won't agree I'm sure, but that doesn't change the fact that many people view it that way.) One doesn't have to be particularly religious to have such a view of marriage. And statements by some psychological organizations such as the APA (which do not constitute "the entire medical and psychological community" as some here have suggested) haven't helped that much either--they've been wrong before on other things. And if one reads the statements carefully, they are not tacit approval of homosexuality, but rather indicate that the organization takes the stance (in general--doesn't mean all it's members) that homosexuality does not amount to mental illness and that they can generally raise children without harmful effects to the children. I have no problems with any of that, but it doesn't have much bearing on whether marriage as an institution should be redefined. And for that matter, we must not fall into the trap of assuming that just because one is a psychologist or doctor, his or her's is the last infallible word on a topic. 
 
 And there's the whole other matter of whether or not, from a constitutional standpoint, you are truly being "denied" a guaranteed right in the first place. If one views the supposed constitutional right to marriage as something between a man and a woman, you are not being denied anything at all. You just prefer not to marry. 
 
 I think these "rights" you seek are really simply govt. benefits, in the same sense as social security. There's nothing magical about govt. recognition of marriage; it simply amounts to criteria for the application of benefits, just as age (over 62) amounts to criteria for the application of social security benefits. As I have made clear, I would not be against you getting whatever benefits you need, as long as we can avoid redefining marriage as an institution in doing so. But because the gay lobby insists on it by only wanting marriage as a criteria to get these benefits, it becomes glaringly clear that it is not so much 'rights' that you all are seeking, but validation and social acceptance. That's fine, but why tamper with the institution of marriage to get it?

 Begging the Question
 

 
 That is not Begging the Question if it can be shown that gay people are denied equality. Regarding equality, the definition might be agreed upon as access to an equivalent set of rights and benefits under the law. In a quick inspection, it would appear that everyone has the same rights and this would imply that everyone has equal rights. But a more detailed inspection reveals that the right to marriage is both designed for and put into use to grant benefits specifically to those who engage in heterosexual relationships. This same set of benefits does not currently exist for those who engage in homosexual relationships. It stands to reason then, that in order to recieve the benefits of marriage, a homosexual man must change his beliefs, behavior, and person he has fallen in love with. A heterosexual man must do nothing. My conclusion is that access to the same set of rights is not the same thing as access to an equal set of rights.
 
 As an example, I might provide benefits for people who worship at a Buddhist church. Although everyone has the same access to these benefits, the benefits are not equal. Christians would need to change their religion, their way of life, everything they believe in so that they could get these benefits.
 
 Further consideration makes it certain that it is the criteria one must meet in order to qualify for these benefits that makes them unequal. When the criteria says, "By the way, you must give up your homosexual relationship and engage in a heterosexual relationship to qualify," then inequality could be no more clear.
